title: 16 Sides
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/OpZeZ2DXUv-screenshot-2020-02-18-at-91034-am.png?width=500"}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"On a circle sixteen points, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", ... "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_{16}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", are equally spaced. What is the measure of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\angle A_7 A_9 A_{13}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" in degrees?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/LOzBTIoezh-b2002018a.png?width=400"}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Choose any point from "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_{14}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (I have chosen "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for convenience) to make "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_2A_7A_9A_{13}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" a "},{"type":"text","text":"cyclic quadrilateral","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":", so that we can use its properties. Let the center of the circle be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"O"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  Then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\angle A_7OA_{13} = \dfrac 6{16} \times 360^\circ = 135^\circ"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". For the same chord the angle it extends at the circumference is half that of the angle at the center.  Therefore "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\angle A_7A_2A_{13} = \dfrac {135^\circ}2 = 67.5^\circ"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Since the opposite angles of a cyclic quadrilateral add to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"180^\circ"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\angle A_7A_9A_{13} = 180^\circ - 67.5^\circ = \boxed{112.5}^\circ"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

                                            That's brilliant, I was thinking of cyclic quadrilaterals in solution but could not create any such concrete equations. Great :)

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"O"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be the center of the circle and draw "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_{13}O"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A_{7}O"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/uploads/QzhXCefGx1-16sides.gif"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\angle A_{13}OA_{7}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (the angle that subtends the major arc) is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{10}{16} \cdot 360° = 225°"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and since an inscribed angle subtended by two points is half the central angle subtended by the same two points, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\theta = \frac{1}{2} \cdot 225° = \boxed{112.5°}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 16th Problem
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We know square roots of non perfect square number is always irrational.Which means digits come out randomly after the decimal point with infinitely long period.Now my question is, can you draw a line which has a length of an irrantional number(for example:√2)?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We can.
For Example: Draw a 1 unit Perpendicular on the terminal point or starting of another 1 unit segment.Then connect the open points. Then the length would be √2.                                                                Since Pythagorean theorem says          √(1^2+1^2 )=√2"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 16th Problem 2016

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned} 
\dfrac{3z}{\sqrt{198x^2y^3z}} & = \dfrac{3z}{\sqrt{9 × x^2 × z^2 × 22 × y × z}}\\ \\
& = \dfrac{3z}{3xz × \sqrt{22yz}}\\ \\
& = \dfrac{1}{x \sqrt{22yz}}\\ \\
\text{Multiplying numerator and denominator by} \sqrt{22yz}\\
& = \dfrac{\sqrt{22yz}}{x × {\sqrt{22yz}}^2}\\ \\
& = \boxed{\dfrac{\sqrt{22yz}}{22xyz}} \end{aligned}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}
